case_name: Hitkarini Sabha, Jabalpur v. Municipal Corporation

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 702 and 703 of 1967 are before the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 702 and 703 of 1967. Appeals from the judgment and order dated September 28

facts.text: Appeals arise from judgment and order dated September 28, 1960 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in Misc. First Appeals Nos. 12 and 16 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the judgment and order dated September 28, 1960 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in Misc. First Appeals Nos. 12 and 16 of 1958.

facts.text: Plots Nos. 670, 671 and 735 situate in Madan Mahal Extension area, Jabalpur were acquired by the State Government under the Land Acquisition Act 1894 for constructing the Home Science College.

anchor.surface_text: Plots Nos. 670, 671 and 735 situate in Madan Mahal Extension area, Jabalpur were acquired by the State Government under the Land Acquisition Act 1894, hereinafter called the Act, for companystructing the Home Science College.

facts.text: The appeals are mainly concerned with Plot No. 670.

anchor.surface_text: In the present appeals we are companycerned mainly with Plot No. 670.

facts.text: On August 31, 1940, a deed of lease was executed on behalf of the Municipal Corporation granting a lease free of premium to the Hitkarini Sabha, Jabalpur (appellant).

anchor.surface_text: On August 31, 1940, a deed of lease had been executed on behalf of the Municipal Corporation granting a lease free of premium to the Hitkarini Sabha, Jabalpur, which is the appellant before us.

facts.text: The lease was for 10 Acres comprising Plot No. 670 and another strip of land measuring 0.621 Acres.

anchor.surface_text: The laese was in respect of 10 Acres of land companyprising Plot No. 670 and another strip of land measuring 0.621 Acres as described in the deed and delineated in the plan annexed thereto.

facts.text: The period of the lease was 30 years for locating and running the Hitkarini City College.

anchor.surface_text: The period of the lease was 30 years and the purpose for which the land was to be used was for locating and running the Hitkarini City College.

facts.text: Appellant was to pay yearly rent of Rs. 5 for 10 acres and Re. 1 for the other strip besides rates and taxes.

anchor.surface_text: Amongst other terms and companyditions the, appellant was to pay a yearly rent of Rs. .5 , for 1 0 acres and Re. 1 for the other strip of land besides, paying, and discharging all rates and taxes-etc.

facts.text: The lease entitled the appellant to renewal on terms and conditions as agreed between parties.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, on the expiry of the lease, was entitled to have the same renewed on-, such terms and companyditions as might be agreed between the parties.

facts.text: Appellant built a college hostel on the land and used the attached ground as playground.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant had built a, companylege hostel on the aforesaid land and had also used the attached ground as playground for students.

facts.text: Collector of Jabalpur made award dated July 18, 1955 assessing compensation at As.0/8/- per sq. ft. for lands in all three plots.

anchor.surface_text: The Collector of Jabalpur, by his award dated July 18, 1955 dealt with the claims filed by the appellant and the Municipal Corporation and after disposing of certain preliminary objections he assessed the companypensation for the lands in all the three plots at As.0/8/-per sq. ft.

facts.text: Collector held appellant was a lessee for the term in the lease-deed dated August 31, 1940.

anchor.surface_text: According to the Collector the appellant was number merely a lessee or tenant-at-will as companytended by the Corporation but was a lessee for the term mentioned in the lease-deed dated August 31, 1940, the lease having been made for a specific purpose, i.e. for locating and running a City College.

facts.text: Apportionment made between appellant and Corporation for Plot No. 670 by Collector.

anchor.surface_text: As regards Plot No. 670 the apportionment was made between the appellant The appellant and the Corporation were dissatisfied with the award of the Collector.

facts.text: Applications for reference made under s. 18 of the Act by appellant and Corporation.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant and the Corporation were dissatisfied with the award of the Collector. Applications for reference were made under s. 18  1  of the Act.

facts.text: Additional District Judge held price should be 10 As. per sq. ft. and equal compensation for plot No. 670 to appellant and Municipal Corporation.

anchor.surface_text: The Additional District Judge held that the price should be 10 As. per sq. ft. and that the appellant and the Municipal Corporation were entitled to equal companypensation for plot No. 670.

facts.text: Corporation and appellant filed appeals to High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The Corporation and the appellant filed appeals to the High Court.

facts.text: High Court affirmed the price fixed by Additional District Judge at As. 0/8/- per sq. ft.

anchor.surface_text: The decision of the Additional District Judge, fixing the price of the land at As. 0/8/- per sq. ft. was affirmed.

facts.text: High Court held lease deed executed by Administrator when Corporation superseded was ineffective to convey leasehold interest.

anchor.surface_text: As regards the dispute regarding apportionment the High Court held, following a decision of a Division Bench of the same companyrt in Dagdulal v. Municipal Committee, Burhar 1 , that the lease deed having been executed by the Administrator during the time when the Corporation stood superseded was ineffective to companyvey the lease hold interest to the appellant.

facts.text: High Court held tenancy created by implication due to payment and acceptance of rent, continuing on terms in lease deed.

anchor.surface_text: However, the appellant had been paving refit at the stipulated rate which had been accepted for a long time by the Corporation. It amounted, therefore, to the creation of a tenancy by necessary implication and the relationship of landlord and tenant came into existence. On the character of tenancy... the tenancy companytinued on the terms companytained in the lease deed.

facts.text: High Court held renewal clause uncertain and vague, not forming valid contract for renewal.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court then proceeded to say - The lease deed in this case was executed on 31- 8 1940 and was for a period of thirty years. ... It appears to. us that the clause  1  1960 M. P. L. J. 627 is uncertain and vague and does number form a valid companytract for renewal of the lease.

facts.text: High Court made apportionment on actuarial basis in ratio 1038:962 between appellant and Corporation.

anchor.surface_text: The apportionment was made on acturial basis between the appellant and the Corporation in the ratio of 1038 962.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeals raise issues of quantum of compensation and apportionment.

anchor.surface_text: Before us two matters have been sought to be raised. One one relates to the quantum of companypensation awarded by the learned Additional District Judge and the other to the apportionment between the appellant and the Corporation.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds renewal clause should not be considered as High Court found it ineffective and lease void.

anchor.surface_text: We are wholly unable to companyprehend how any lease companyld be spelt out of the deed dated August 31, 1940 for a period of 30 years companytaining the renewal clause which has already been mentioned. ... In our opinion the High Court companyld riot have done so.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds tenancy is from month to month under s.106 Transfer of Property Act.

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 106 of that Act the ,tenancy, in the present case, companyld be only from month to month because the immovable property had number been leased out  1   1960  MP.L.J. 627. for agricultural or manufacturing purpose in which case the lease would have been from year to year.

facts.text: Supreme Court upholds quantum of compensation at 10/ per sq. ft. by Additional District Judge.

anchor.surface_text: We,therefore, find that the price at-/10/per sq. ft. allowed by the Additional District judge, is number unreasonable if anything it errs on the generous side.

facts.text: High Court in Dagdulal v. Municipal Committee, Burhar held Administrator had no power to sell property vested in Government.

anchor.surface_text: In the decision of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in Dagdulals 1  case the view had been expressed that so long as Municipal Committee was number reconstituted the ownership of the property stood transferred by operation of law to the State Government and therefore the Administrator had numberpower whatsoever to sell the property which had vested in the Government.

facts.text: Lease executed by In-Charge and Secretary of Municipal Committee when superseded.

anchor.surface_text: At the time the lease was executed A.I.R. 1961 Mys. 29. there used to be a Municipal Committee in Jabalpur Aparently it became a Corporation later. The Committee was superseded in-Charge of the Committee Jabalpur as also Secretary of the Municipal Committee had signed the lease on behalf of that Committee.

facts.text: High Court found final resolution was for grant of license not lease.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, however, found on the evidence produced before the Additional District Judge that the final resolution passed by the Municipal Committee was only for the grunt of a license and number a lease to the appellant.

facts.text: About 70,000 sq. ft. of acquired sites required for roads and drains.

anchor.surface_text: We had asked the Corporation to calculate how much area out of the acquired sites would be required to be left open for roads and drains and they have calculated that about 70,000 sq. ft. would have to be left open for this pur- pose.

facts.text: Corporation estimated cost of developing roads and drains at Rs. 8,500/- .

anchor.surface_text: Besides leaving so much area open, companyts will have to be incurred in developing the roads, and drains for which the Corporation has estimated the companyt to be Rs. 8,500/-.

arguments.claim: Administrator had no power to grant lease as property vested in State Government

anchor.surface_text: In the decision of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in Dagdulals 1  case the view had been expressed that so long as Municipal Committee was number reconstituted the ownership of the property stood transferred by operation of law to the State Government and therefore the Administrator had numberpower whatsoever to sell the property which had vested in the Government.

holdings.text: The deed of lease dated August 31, 1940 executed by the In-Charge and Secretary of the superseded Municipal Committee was wholly null and void as they had no power to grant a lease for 30 years.

anchor.surface_text: We are wholly unable to comprehend how any lease could be spelt out of the deed dated August 31, 1940 for a period of 30 years containing the renewal clause which has already been mentioned. If the officer who executed the lease deed had no power

holdings.reasoning_summary: Officer lacked authority as property vested in State Government upon supersession per Dagdulal precedent; final resolution was for license not lease.

holdings.text: A tenancy from month to month was created by necessary implication due to payment and acceptance of rent, governed by section 106 of the Transfer of Property Act.

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 106 of that Act the ,tenancy, in the present case, could be only from month to month because the immovable property had not been leased out  1   1960  MP.L.J. 627. for agricultural or manufacturing purpose

holdings.reasoning_summary: Invalid deed does not prevent tenancy by conduct; s.106 applies as non-agricultural/manufacturing use, defaulting to monthly tenancy.

holdings.text: The High Court could not give effect to the renewal clause while deciding apportionment as no valid lease existed and tenancy was only month to month.

anchor.surface_text: The only matter which requires determination is whether the High Court, while deciding the question of apportionment, should have given due affect to the renewal clause. In our opinion the High Court could riot have done so.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Void deed precludes 30-year term or renewal; unnecessary to decide renewal clause validity independently; s.106 governs term.

holdings.text: The renewal clause was uncertain and vague, not forming a valid enforceable contract.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court then proceeded to say - The lease deed in this case was executed on 31- 8 1940 and was for a period of thirty years. ... It appears to. us that the clause  1  1960 M. P. L. J. 627 is uncertain and vague and does number form a valid

holdings.reasoning_summary: Terms left entirely to future agreement without fixed basis; s.29 Contract Act voids uncertain agreements; High Court view affirmed implicitly.

holdings.text: Quantum of compensation at 10 annas per sq. ft. is reasonable, considering potentialities via comparable sales adjusted for development costs.

anchor.surface_text: We,therefore, find that the price at-/10/per sq. ft. allowed by the Additional District judge, is number unreasonable if anything it errs on the generous side. We have numbermanner of doubt that the High Court had taken all the factors into

holdings.reasoning_summary: Lower courts used willing vendor-purchaser test with comparables; deducted roads/drains (70,000 sq.ft.), costs (Rs.8500), yielding generous value.

holdings.text: Market value in acquisition must account for land's position and potentialities via willing vendor-willing purchaser hypothesis.

anchor.surface_text: where the land to be valued possesses some unusual or unique features as regards its position or its potentialities the court determining the market value will have to ascertain as best as it can from the materials before it what a willing vendor

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applied Raja Vyricherla precedent; lower courts properly considered via adjusted comparables despite special location near station/business.

anchor.surface_text: the High Court held, following a decision of a Division Bench of the same court in Dagdulal v. Municipal Committee, Burhar 1 , that the lease deed having been executed by the Administrator during the time when the Corporation stood superseded was ineffective to convey the lease hold interest to the appellant.

precedents.cited_proposition: lease deed having been executed by the Administrator during the time when the Corporation stood superseded was ineffective to convey the lease hold interest

precedents.citation: Ramaswami v. Rjajagopala I.L.R. I I Mad. 260

anchor.surface_text: It has been held in Ramaswami v. Rjajagopala  I.L.R. I I Mad. 260  that a lease whereby a tenant agreed to pay whatever rent the Landlord might fix was void for uncertainty. The apportionment was made on acturial basis between the appellant and the Corporation in the ratio of 1038 962.

precedents.cited_proposition: a lease whereby a tenant agreed to pay whatever rent the Landlord might fix was void for uncertainty

precedents.citation: H. V. Rajan v. C. N.Gopal Others. 1

anchor.surface_text: Our attention has been invited to a judgment of the Mysore High Court in H. V. Rajan v. C. N.Gopal Others.  1 There the relevant portion of the renewal clause was lessee shall have the option of five years but subject only to such terms and conditions as may be mutually agreed upon.

precedents.case_name: H. V. Rajan v. C. N. Gopal Others
precedents.cited_proposition: ordinarily the renewal clause in a lease deed was an important term of the agreement and the courts would be reluctant to ignore that clause on the ground that it was vague unless on a reasonable construction no meaning could be attached to it; an agreement to renew the lease without more must be deemed to be an agreement to renew as per the original terms; even if dependent on agreement between parties the clause merely provided for agreement on reasonable terms and courts could step in

anchor.surface_text: In the decision of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in Dagdulals 1  case the view had been expressed that so long as Municipal Committee was number reconstituted the ownership of the property stood transferred by operation of law to the State Government and therefore the Administrator had numberpower whatsoever to sell the property which had vested in the Government.

precedents.cited_proposition: so long as Municipal Committee was not reconstituted the ownership of the property stood transferred by operation of law to the State Government and therefore the Administrator had no power whatsoever to sell the property which had vested in the Government

precedents.citation: Raja Vyrigherla Marayana Gajapatiraju v. The Revenue Divisional Officer Vizagapatam 1

anchor.surface_text: It is true, as pointed out in Raja Vyrigherla Marayana Gajapatiraju v. The Revenue Divisional Officer Vizagapatam 1  that where the land to be valued possesses some unusual or unique features as regards its position or its potentialities the court determining the market value will have to ascertain as best as it can from the materials before it what a willing vendor might reasonably expect to obtain from a willing purchaser for the land in that particular position and with those particular potentialities.

precedents.case_name: Raja Vyricherla Narayana Gajapatiraju v. The Revenue Divisional Officer Vizagapatam
precedents.cited_proposition: where the land to be valued possesses some unusual or unique features as regards its position or its potentialities the court determining the market value will have to ascertain as best as it can from the materials before it what a willing vendor might reasonably expect to obtain from a willing purchaser for the land in that particular position and with those particular potentialities
